DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY AUTHORIZATION ACT

extension.searchTitle: DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY AUTHORIZATION ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 123

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the bill, as amended, was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Department of Homeland Security Authorization Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measure:<P/>H.R. 2825, amended, to amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to make certain improvements in the laws administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 386 yeas to 41 nays, Roll No. 403.

titleInfo.title: KING COVE ROAD LAND EXCHANGE ACT

extension.searchTitle: KING COVE ROAD LAND EXCHANGE ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 123

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: King Cove Road Land Exchange Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 218, to provide for the exchange of Federal land and non-Federal land in the State of Alaska for the construction of a road between King Cove and Cold Bay, by a yea-and-nay vote of 248 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 406.<P/>Rejected the Garamendi motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Natural Resources with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by voice vote.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-27 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Tsongas amendment (No. 1 printed in part C of H. Rept. 115-235) that sought to require mitigation measures, previously adopted in Public Law 111-11, to ensure that impacts to migratory birds, wildlife, and wetlands are minimized (by a recorded vote of 190 ayes to 234 noes, Roll No. 404); and<P/>Grijalva amendment (No. 3 printed in part C of H. Rept. 115-235) that sought to prohibit the Act from taking effect until $20 million in federal funds D815given to Alaska for transportation purposes in King Cove is repaid to the Federal Government (by a recorded vote of 167 ayes to 260 noes, Roll No. 405).

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: King Cove Road Land Exchange Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 218, to provide for the exchange of Federal land and non-Federal land in the State of Alaska for the construction of a road between King Cove and Cold Bay, by a yea-and-nay vote of 248 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 406.<P/>Rejected the Garamendi motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Natural Resources with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by voice vote.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-27 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Tsongas amendment (No. 1 printed in part C of H. Rept. 115-235) that sought to require mitigation measures, previously adopted in Public Law 111-11, to ensure that impacts to migratory birds, wildlife, and wetlands are minimized (by a recorded vote of 190 ayes to 234 noes, Roll No. 404); and<P/>Grijalva amendment (No. 3 printed in part C of H. Rept. 115-235) that sought to prohibit the Act from taking effect until $20 million in federal funds D815given to Alaska for transportation purposes in King Cove is repaid to the Federal Government (by a recorded vote of 167 ayes to 260 noes, Roll No. 405).

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: King Cove Road Land Exchange Act
King Cove Road Land Exchange Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 218, to provide for the exchange of Federal land and non-Federal land in the State of Alaska for the construction of a road between King Cove and Cold Bay, by a yea-and-nay vote of 248 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 406.

The House passed H.R. 218, to provide for the exchange of Federal land and non-Federal land in the State of Alaska for the construction of a road between King Cove and Cold Bay, by a yea-and-nay vote of 248 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 406.
